author: Ts. Haniff Nasir
bio: Industrial Analyst | Process & Analytics Specialists | Championing Data Literacy, Production Optimization, and BI for Students & Professionals | Excel, SQL, Power BI, Chemicals, Engineering, and Operations
text:
I'll embark a new journey starting next week - Analytics Engineering. 
Guess what? I've discovered a book that's truly intriguing and valuable. 

Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering by Packt offers a comprehensive guide through the analytics engineering landscape, from basic principles to advanced techniques in data ingestion, warehousing, and modeling.

Authored by seven industry professionals, the book equips readers with the necessary tools to convert raw data into meaningful insights, addressing key areas like data pipelines, cloud analytics, data governance, and the art of collaborative coding.

Who should read this book?
Data engineer
Data analyst
Developer
Analytics engineer
Data Professionals

Title: Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering
Authors: Dumky de Wilde, Fanny Kassapian, Jovan Gligorevic, Juan Manuel Perafan, Lasse Benninga, Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez, Tais Laurindo Pereira
Link: https://packt.link/aQ9uz

Thanks to Nivedita Singh for the opportunity to review such excellent books pertinent to our industry.

I'm looking forward to learn and explore further in the realm of data analytics and visualization.

P.S.: What book would you recommend for my upcoming reading and review? Share your suggestions in the comments section below.

P.S.S: Full book review coming soon

#HNShare #Analytics #Engineer #DataAnalyst

author: Dumky de Wilde
text: We wrote the book I wish Id had five years ago and last week I was able to present it at our 10th analytics engineering meetup. There is a figure-it-out-yourself mentality in the data & analytics field that I enjoy tremendously, but sometimes it is nice to have a shortcut. The Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering (https://amzn.to/43KxIik) is one of those shortcuts. Each one of the amazing authors brings their own perspective and experience to get you up to speed on data warehouses, data modelling, data ingestion, observability, stakeholder management and navigating the tech landscape. Thanks for the journey Juan Manuel Perafan, Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez Fanny Kassapian Tais Laurindo Pereira Lasse Benninga Jovan Gligorevic

author: Johan van de Werken
bio: Freelance Data Analyst / Analytics Engineer | GA4BigQuery.com | GA4Dataform.com
text:
I recently had the pleasure of reading 'Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering' by Dumky de Wilde, Juan Manuel Perafan, Fanny Kassapian, Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez et al.

This book has been an eye-opener, affirming that I can now confidently call myself an analytics engineer, a role I've been effectively fulfilling for several years already without realizing it.

If you work in the data field, especially at the intersection of these roles, this book is written for you: https://lnkd.in/eKAVgMUZ

author: Tais Laurindo Pereira
text:
Book alert  

After one year of intense work next to our full-time consultant jobs, I'm happy to announce that our book Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering is out!  

Our idea for writing was to guide those starting in the field in a tool-agnostic way. Analytics Engineering is quite a new area, and there needs to be more literature about it. This book aims to provide a set of best practices to contribute to a solid knowledge base for people working with it. 

I want to thank all the co-authors - Fanny Kassapian, Juan Manuel Perafan, Lasse Benninga, Dumky de Wilde, Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez, Jovan Gligorevic (yes, we are many) for your awesome work. Also I'd like to thank my Xebia colleagues - Juan Venegas for the additional editing and Guillermo Sanchez Dionis and Padraic Slattery, Ph.D. for the additional technical review.

Lastly, I want to thank Xebia for supporting us during this process, and Packt for trusting us with the task. 

When I left my home country back in 2019 I'd never have imagined to achieve something like this. Crazy where life can take you sometimes!

author: Dumky de Wilde
text:
Ever since I first started out working with data over 10 years ago Ive had two questions that haunted me.
- Why does everyone seem to mean something different with the words data or analytics?
- Why do we need to move and copy data if it is already there?

Do you recognize this? 
- You mention 'analytics' and someone starts talking about cookies while others will refer to their sales dashboard in Excel 
- 'data platform' can mean we've connected every source individually to our dashboard or we run a Terraformed, distributed data lakehouse for streaming and batch as a single source of truth
- Google 'SQL Tutorial' and you find how to set up your Postgres database for storing transactional data instead of how to aggregate and combine web sessions and sales data
- GTM either means go to market or Google Tag Manager, depending on your audience

I still do not have a clear answer to both questions, but I find that understanding other teams, roles and their responsibilities and vocabulary helps tremendously to avoid confusion. If you ever find yourself duplicating data again, ask yourself if it facilitates:
- a different usage pattern
- a different set of permissions
- cost efficiency

These types of questions to me are what analytics engineering is trying to solve. This is also why I'm soon publishing a book on the fundamentals of analytics engineering with Fanny Kassapian, Juan Manuel Perafan, Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez, Tais Laurindo Pereira, Lasse Benninga, Jovan Gligorevic

author: Connor Dickson
text:
The winners have been chosen! 

Packt and I did a giveaway with five copies of Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering. We had over 80 submissions, thanks for all the interest folks! 

I took all the entries, put them in an excel file, and used python to randomly select five winners. See the screenshot for a closer look at the selection process. 

The winners of the physical copies of Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering are:

Md Rakib Hasan

Matias Vizcaino

The winners of the ebook version are: 

Joshua Kofile

Erfan Hesami

Tristan Baylock, CPA

I'll send each of the winners a DM so they can get their copies of the book. 

Thanks to everyone for participating. If you didn't win, you can always pick up a copy on Amazon, or on Packt's website. 

#datawithdickson

author: Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez
text:
Exciting news   

Look Mom I am on the cover! 
Jokes aside, I'm thrilled to announce the launch of our book,  Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering! [ https://amzn.to/3TM3I2f ] After countless hours of dedication and juggling our full-time consulting roles, we've crafted a resource that we believe will benefit both newcomers and experienced professionals in the ever-evolving field of analytics engineering.   
  
Our goal in writing this book was to provide a tool-agnostic, step-by-step guide that simplifies complex concepts and outlines best practices to help build a robust foundation in analytics engineering.   
  
A massive shoutout to my incredible co-authors - Fanny Kassapian , Juan Manuel Perafan, Lasse Benninga, Dumky de Wilde, Tais Laurindo Pereira, and Jovan Gligorevic - your dedication and expertise have truly made this book a reality!  Special thanks to Juan Venegas for editing support, and Guillermo Sanchez Dionis and Padraic Slattery, Ph.D. for their valuable technical reviews.   
  
Huge appreciation goes out to Xebia for their unwavering support throughout this journey, specially to Bram Ochsendorf and Giovanni Lanzani, and Packt for entrusting us with this project.   
 
If you're looking to sharpen your analytics engineering skills or dive into this exciting field, our book is ready to guide you on your journey.   
  
#analyticsengineering #newbooklaunch #datascience #accomplishments #teamworkmakesthedreamwork

author: Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez
text:
Come and share with us! https://bit.ly/49mDsjM 

Recently I had the great experience to launch a new book Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering ( https://amzn.to/3TM3I2f ), I learnt a lot from my co-authors and colleagues while working on the research and edition of the book.

In this area of knowledge that is quickly evolving, one of the best ways to share and gain knowledge is through meeting people that have the same goals and struggles than us as Analytics Engineers.

Come join us in Amsterdam for the next edition of the Analyticis Engineering meetup on April 10th, we will have great speakers, interesting talks and free pizza!
If you have any question, please let me know.

See you there!

Schedule:
17:30   Pizza.
18:15   GitHub: Learn fast, develop faster & keep it secure
18:45   Break.
19:00   Data Fortification: Safeguarding sensitive insights in data development
19:30   Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering: An Introduction to Building End-to-End Analytics Solutions
19:40 -  Drinks

author: Jovan Gligorevic
bio: Analytics Engineer | Helping Bitpanda win in Europe
text:
I am excited to announce that our book Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering is out! After a year of intense work next to our regular day-to-day I am happy with the result 

The book will soon be out in paperback and as a Kindle eBook very soon! Will keep you posted! 

I am confident that our book will contribute to a better understanding of the relatively new and growing field of Analytics Engineering. It reads like a beginner-friendly guide to get started within the field, explaining the underlying principles behind analytics engineering and providing best practices and examples on building end-to-end analytics solutions in the cloud.

Are you interested in data warehousing, dbt, data modelling, orchestration, development, deployment and analytics? Then give this book a read!   

I want to sincerely thank all the co-authors - Fanny Kassapian, Juan Manuel Perafan, Lasse Benninga, Dumky de Wilde, Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez and Tais Laurindo Pereira, for your awesome work. I'd like to thank my former Xebia colleagues - Juan Venegas for your dedication in helping with editing and Guillermo Sanchez Dionis and Padraic Slattery, Ph.D. for the technical review.

Happy reading!

#packt #xebia #analyticsengineering #dbt #data #datamodelling

author: Juan Manuel Perafan
bio: Co-Author Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering | dbt Community Award Recipient
text:
In case you missed it, Select Star is giving away a couple of copies of Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering. 

You only need to write an Analytics Engineering tip in the comments.

author: Connor Dickson
text:
The concept of analytics engineering is comparatively new. 

Taking data engineering tasks and mashing it with the responsibilities of data analysts is somewhat novel. 

Thats why Im excited that Packt wrote a book on the Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering and sent me a copy! 

Their book touches on topics such as:

 Building Data Pipelines 

 Data Strategy 

Building a Data Platform 

If you want to learn more about analytics engineering, youre in luck, Packt is giving away five copies (2 physical, 3 ebooks) of Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering! 

If you want a chance to win a copy, just comment on this post and Ill pick the winners with a RNG.  

The winners will be tagged in a future post, and receive a message from me. Dont fall for any scams. Only my verfied account will be messaging you about the winners. 

#datawithdickson #analyticsengineering

author: Dumky de Wilde
text: Whether you are an analyst, data engineer or an AI bot, you likely care about the quality and availability of the data you work with. This afternoon I'll be talking about exactly that in the context of our recently released book The Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering and how it can help you navigate the muddy waters of data and analytics in organisations. The e-book is out now, and you can pre-order the good ol' paper version.

author: Giovanni Lanzani
text:

So here's a follow-up: in Q1, besides everything else, we also published a book with Packt:

author: Juan Manuel Perafan
bio: Co-Author Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering | dbt Community Award Recipient
text:
I had the pleasure of hosting my co-author, Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez, on the latest episode of SQL Lingua Franca. 

We talked about the role of an analytics engineer, his career before he became an analytics engineer, and how you can start your pet project using (near) zero-cost tools like DuckDB, dbt, and BigQuery. 

As expected, we also shared some fun anecdotes of the making of Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering Packt.

Spotify: https://lnkd.in/eZuJDEnY
YouTube: https://lnkd.in/eYTWmbFT

author: Ricardo Angel Granados Lopez
bio: Consultant at Xebia Data | Co-author of Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering
text:
Excited to share my first podcast appearance in the Netherlands. 

I am glad it was on the SQL Lingua Franca podcast with Juan Manuel Perafan! We had a great conversation about our recent book Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering and even delved into my personal journey, starting in Med school and eventually becoming an Analytics Engineer consultant at Xebia Data in the Netherlands.

 In our discussion, we focused on one of the key topics in the book: data modeling. We also shared some fun anecdotes and experiences from the making of Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering published by Packt.

 Don't miss out on this engaging conversation! You can listen to the podcast on:
Spotify: https://lnkd.in/eZuJDEnY
YouTube: https://lnkd.in/eYTWmbFT
Book: https://amzn.to/3TM3I2f

 I'd love for you to tune in and share your thoughts on the podcast. Feel free to connect with me if you have any questions or want to chat more about analytics engineering. Happy listening! #podcast #analyticsengineering #datamodeling #personaljourney

author: Juan Manuel Perafan
bio: Co-Author Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering | dbt Community Award Recipient
text:
When I wrote the chapter on data governance for our book, Fundamentals of Analytics Engineering, I read many books on the subject. In my opinion, many of them lacked technical depth, were too theoretical, or oversimplified the challenges of transforming an organization's IT landscape. 

Recently, I came across the Packt Data Governance Handbook by Wendy Batchelder, and it has quickly become my favorite book on data governance. It is fresh off the press, and I still need to finish the second half, but it has been super helpful! I can't recommend it enough!
